TextView.android:text: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is defined as any degree of glucose intolerance with onset or first recognition during pregnancy. Approximately 7% of all pregnancies are complicated by GDM, resulting in more than 200,000 cases annually. The prevalence may range from 1 to 14% of all pregnancies, depending on the population studied and the diagnostic tests employed.

There are many types of high blood pressures during pregnancy. Like Gestational hypertension that develops after 20 week, chronic hypertension that can occur before pregnancy or before 20 weeks, chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia which occurs in women with chronic hypertension before pregnancy who develop worsening high blood pressure and protein in the urine or other blood pressure related complications during pregnancy. There are also ways to reduce this. They are:
 Eat a healthy diet, and especially limit your sodium intake.
 Take your blood pressure medications the way you are supposed to.
 Keep all your prenatal appointments.
 Stay physically active, although your healthcare provider may prescribe bed rest if you develop preeclampsia
